_exec_summary.SummaryText:

the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) 29 CFR 1910.111 AÂ¿Storage and Handling of
Anhydrous AmmoniaAÂ¿, and the Iowa Fertilize Law. Annual inspections by Iowa Department of Agriculture
and Land Stewardship (IDALS) are made on facilities and portable nurse tanks. Frequent site inspections are
made by management and safety consultants. Equipment inspections, maintenance and employee training
are conducted prior to every application season.
FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:
There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that caused any death,
injuries, or significant damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries,
evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage. Even though this site has had
no releases, it still coordinates annual visits with the local fire department to review the systems and
procedures for response to a leak.
EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:
This facility has a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard 29 CFR 1910.38. The
facility has also provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know
information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA), and has coordinated with local emergency responders.
PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:
Safety improvement is an on-going process at this facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to asses the
maintenance of safe conditions. There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety
recommendations for implantation at this time.

Westco Agronomy Company, LLC - Paton
FACILITY POLICY:
West Central Cooperative is committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.
Bi-annual inspections and maintenance are required on all storage facilities, loading and unloading facilities,
application equipment and portable tanks. All employees who handle anhydrous ammonia are required to
attend bi-annual training which emphas the properties of anhydrous ammonia, the affects of anhydrous
ammonia on the human body, operating procedures, emergency procedures, and emergency first aid. PPE,
including gloves, goggles, hard hats, emergency water, and sturdy work cloths & shoes are required
whenever handling anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, this facility is prepared to
work with local fire departments, LEPCAÂ¿s, law enforcement, or other authorities to mitigate the impact of
the release to people and the environment.
FACILITY INFORMATION:
The primary activity at this facility is the storage and blending of fertilizers for sale to farmer customers.
Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and kept in (a) storage tank(s) until distributed to customers in
mobile nurse tanks for use as a nitrogen fertilizer. The storage tank(s), several anhydrous ammonia nurse
tanks, risers for filling the nurse tanks, pumps and controls, lighting and safety equipment are all part of the
facilities anhydrous ammonia operation. The facility is staffed during seasonal operating hours, and is
secured when not in operation. Security includes area lighting, closing and locking the main valve (belly
valve) from the storage tank(s), locking out power to pumps, closing fill hose end valves and locking them in a
box that prevents unauthorized access to them, locking nurse tank unloading valves, and walk-thru
inspections.
ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM:
This facility has implemented the provisions of AÂ¿Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of
Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61-1AÂ¿ published
